results.title: Seachange = Sea change. Series 3. Ep. 1-7
results.brief_description: Series 3, episodes 1-7. “Best Laid Plans” (Dir: Steve Jodrell) Bulldozers arrive the Bay and the council reveals plans to tear down the boatshed - Max’s house; Karen quits the police force and leaves Angus, and Max and Laura finally kiss. “How Much Greener was my Neighbour’s Valley?” (Dir: Steve Jodrell); The CFA dance has a Latin theme this year, and a passionate Latin dance instructor arrives in town, with eyes for Max who falls for her charms; and Jules is arrested for theft and must appear before Laura. “Hungi Jury” (Dir: Mandy Smith); Laura joins the women’s auxiliary and is cut down to size by club president Vicki Drury before she even begins; Max and Carmen begin a passionate affair and Angus quits as the court clerk. “Bonfire of the VCRs” (Dir: Mandy Smith); Carmen leaves town and Meredith believes Max is responsible for her niece leaving; the town join forces to save Phrani from being forced to declare bankruptcy and Meredith and Bob form an alliance when plans are revealed to build a tunnel between Pearl Bay and Port Deakin. “Pipeline” (Dir: David Cameron); Angus is approached by a local surfing legend to design a new surfboard and is thrilled until his template board is stolen and he decides to take the law into his own hands, resulting in a court appearance in front of his ex boss and his ex girlfriend. Laura is swept off her feet by a new man in town. “Adversely Possessed” (Dir: David Cameron); Laura and Warwick become closer although the town seem to like him more than she does; and Miranda joins the staff at The Oyster. “Blowing in the Wind” (Dir: Stuart McDonald); Laura settles into her relationship with Warwick, Sergeant Grey’s trumpet is destroyed by a disgruntled prisoner and Griff decides to settle down.

results.title: Seachange = Sea change. Series 2. Ep. 8-13
results.brief_description: Series 2, episodes 8-13. “Manna From Heaven: (Dir: Steve Jodrell); Pearl Bay is being destroyed by a mysterious insect that has devoured Laura’s House, the courtroom and even the Tropical Star. Heather reveals her parent’s identity to the entire town and the town reveals a shocking secret. “Playing with fire” (Dir: Brendan Maher); Pearl Bay is suffering the effects of a heat wave; all the men in town become attracted to Laura; Miranda falls for a fireworks expert whose accused of being a pyromaniac and Kevin proposes to Phrani. “Not such great expectations” (Dir: Brendan Maher); Bob convinces Craig to leave school and follow in his footsteps; Laura worries about Rupert’s school marks and Miranda’s career indecision; and Max begins to write his book. “Kitty litter” (Dir: Paul Moloney); Laura discovers Trudi living with Jack and admits she is afraid of being replaced as their mother; Harold’s estranged wife, Cynthia, appears in court while Harold decides that its time he and Meredith married. “Other peoples’ opinions” (Dir: Paul Moloney); Max is seen leaving Laura’s house - via the bedroom window; Karen is left in charge of the police station while Sergeant Grey goes on holiday and she and Angus set a wedding date. Trevor goes missing and Phrani reveals a secret from her past. “Law and order” (Dir: Deb Cox , Paul Moloney); The bridge between Pearl Bay and Port Deakin is about to reopen, Laura decides to move back to the city, although Rupert and Miranda want to stay in the Bay. Bob joins the Port Deakin council and the courtroom is the scene of a siege.

results.title: Seachange = Sea change. Series 1. Ep. 8-13
results.creator_credit: Sally Ayre-Smith, ABC-TV (Australia) and Artist Services
results.brief_description: Episodes 8-13 of the captivating series “Sea Change” set in the idyllic coastal town of Pearl Bay. The episodes included are “My Own Sweetheart” (directed by Sue Brooks), “Balls and Friggin Goodluck” and “The Accidental Activist” (both directed by Mandy Smith) and “Love Me Or Leave Me”, “Perchance To Dream” and “Sex, Death and Bridges” (directed by Paul Moloney). The series excels not only because of the great writing but the wonderful gallery of characters created by an excellent cast. Stars Sigrid Thornton, David Wenham and John Howard with guest appearances by Bill Hunter, Robert Grubb, Trudy Hellier, Jeremy Callaghan and John Flaus.

results.title: Seachange = Sea change. Series 1. Ep. 1-7
results.creator_credit: Ali Ali, Michael Carson, Ray Argall, Sue Brooks, Sally Ayre-Smith, ABC-TV (Australia) and Artist Services
results.brief_description: Corporate lawyer Laura Gibson (Sigrid Thornton), and her two children find themselves moving from the city to the country when Laura’s marriage falls apart, her husband is imprisoned for embezzlement, and Laura misses out on a partnership. Reluctantly, and with dreams of picking up her life of disarray she begins a position as magistrate in the seaside community of Pearl Bay. They discover that the idyllic location harbours secrets which manifests itself in strange machinations. This tape includes the first seven episodes and stars Sigrid Thornton, David Wenham, John Howard, Bruce Alexander, Kate Atkinson, Kerry Armstrong, and Alice Garner. Episodes directed by Michael Carson, Ray Argall, Ali Ali and Sue Brooks.

results.title: Sea power
results.creator_credit: Vincent Donovan and Australia. Dept. of the Navy
results.brief_description: The aircraft carrier HMAS Melbourne and the Oberon class submarine HMAS Otway take part in an exercise off the eastern coast of Australia. Also seen are the destroyer HMAS Hobart, the supply ship HMAS Stalwart, minesweepers, Navy oil tankers, patrol boats, and some of the Navy’s aircraft.

results.title: Sea area: Forties
results.creator_credit: John Armstrong, British Petroleum and Pelican Films
results.brief_description: The exciting story of how the sponsors developed their Forties Field in the North Sea and were the first to bring oil ashore in quantity. The film also shows how BP have endeavoured to respect the surrounding countryside and the wishes and well-being of local people.

results.title: Sculpture: the forms of life
results.creator_credit: Brooke M. Beebe, Ted Lowry and McGraw-Hill Films
results.brief_description: Various techniques of sculpture as well as a wide variety of sculptures from all cultures and times show how it reflects the spirit of these eras through the vision of the sculptor. The changing nature of sculpture is shown through demonstrations of varying techniques, styles and functions of this three dimensional art.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Brooke M. Beebe, Ted Lowry and McGraw-Hill Films

results.title: Sculpture: process of discovery
results.brief_description: As sculptor Norm Hines searches for the shape he says is hidden in a rock, he discusses his approach to creativity. He has no preconceived form - the shape is decided as it happens.

results.title: Seaweeds
results.creator_credit: Grant Crabtree and National Film Board of Canada
results.brief_description: A fascinating, informative report of marine agronomy as it is being developed on Canada’s Atlantic coast. The film shows the work of the National Research Council’s Atlantic Regional Laboratory at Halifax and of Constance MacFarlane, marine botanist of the Nova Scotia Research Foundation. Efforts are directed at developing the food potentials of marine plants such as dulse, Irish moss, rockweed.
